column1: Cannock () is a town and the administrative centre of the Cannock Chase district
column5: and is one the most populous towns in the district of Cannock Chase in the county of Staffordshire in the West Midlands region of England.

column1: Cannock lies to the north of the West Midlands conurbation on the M6
column3: and to the south of  The Chase
column4: an Area of Outstanding Natural Beauty (AONB). Cannock is served by a railway station on the Chase Line. The town comprises four district council electoral wards and the Cannock South ward includes the civil parish of Bridgtown
column5: but the rest of Cannock is unparished.

column1: Cannock forms part of the Cannock Built-up Area (population 86
column2: 121 in the 2011 census) which also includes Cheslyn Hay

column1: == History ==
Cannock was in the Domesday Book of 1086. It was called Chnoc c.1130
column4: and Canoc in 1198. Cannock is probably Old English cnocc meaning 'hillock'
column5: modified by Norman pronunciation by the insertion of a vowel to Canoc. The name may refer to Shoal Hill
column6: north-west of the town.Cannock was a small rural community until mining increased heavily during the mid-to-late 19th century. The area then continued to grow rapidly with many industries coming to the area because of its proximity to the Black Country and its coal reserves. Cannock's population continued to increase steadily in the 20th century and its slight fall since the 1981 census has been more than compensated for by house-building in the adjoining village of Heath Hayes. The last colliery to close in the town was Mid Cannock in 1967

column1: and the last remaining colliery to close in the Cannock Chase area was Littleton (in Huntington) in 1993.
There is now no heavy industry in the area
column2: and Cannock is home to many commuters working in the surrounding towns and cities.

column1: Cannock Chase German war cemetery is located nearby containing 4
column2: 885 German military dead from the First and Second World Wars. It is managed by the Commonwealth War Graves Commission.

column1: == Geography ==
Cannock is on a south-west facing slope
column2: falling from the highest point on Cannock Chase (244 m) at Castle Ring
column3: to about 148 m in the town centre and 111 m near Wedges Mills. The soil is light with a gravel and clay subsoil
column4: and there are extensive coal measures.

column1: === Climate ===
Cannock has a moderate
column2: temperate climate. See Penkridge weather station for details of average temperature and rainfall figures taken between 1981 and 2010 at the Met Office weather station in Penkridge (around 5 miles (8 km) north-west of Cannock).

column1: === Location ===
Cannock is about 20 miles (30 km) by road north-north-west of Birmingham
column2: 80 miles (130 km) south-south-east of Manchester and 130 miles (210 km) north-west of London. It is 9 to 10 miles (14 to 16 km) by road from many of the nearest towns and cities (Aldridge
column9: Bloxwich and Brownhills (6 miles (10 km)) and Rugeley (7 miles (11 km)) are nearer.

column1: Cities and towns below are in upper case. Only a few of the nearest villages are shown.
== Demography ==
In the decade to 2011 the number of dwellings rose by 7.8% to 13
column2: 152. The ward with the biggest increase (16.1%) was Cannock South.

column1: == Media ==
Cannock has a free weekly local newspaper
column2: the Cannock & Rugeley Chronicle (an edition of the Cannock & Lichfield Chronicle).

column1: Another free weekly
column2: the Chase Post (an edition of the Cannock Chase & Burntwood Post)
column3: ceased publication in November 2011.The Express & Star is a paid-for local newspaper
column4: published in Wolverhampton on weekdays. Televised local news is provided through Midlands Today and Central Tonight
column5: which also serve the wider area of the West Midlands.Cannock is served by the national radio stations
column6: and West Midlands "regional" licences Planet Rock
column7: Smooth Radio West Midlands and Heart West Midlands. The town is also covered by Free Radio Black Country and Shropshire on 97.2 and BBC WM on 95.6 FM.Cannock is served by its own community radio station

column1: == Transport ==
Cannock is located close to the M6
column2: M6 Toll and M54 motorways. There is an extensive network of local buses radiating out from Cannock town centre. The town's main bus operator is Arriva Midlands
column3: who operate the majority of services to and from Cannock bus station linking Stafford
column6: Walsall and Rugeley to name a few.

column1: Cannock railway station closed in 1965 as part of the Beeching cuts but reopened in 1989. It is part of the Rugeley – Cannock – Walsall – Birmingham line operated by West Midlands Trains. Over the years
column4: have increased to unprecedented levels. Services initially were hourly services between Birmingham New Street and Stafford (cut back to Rugeley Trent Valley in 2008). By 2013
column5: usage had become significant enough to warrant electrification of the railway line

column1: The majority of bus services are operated by Arriva Midlands which has a garage to the south of the town centre. In April 2019
column2: National Express West Midlands launched a new timetable on their X51 service to run all day linking Cannock with Birmingham for the first time in several years. Previously this was a peak-time only service.

column1: In May 2019
column2: West Midlands Trains began operating electric trains from this station. The vast majority of services are to Rugeley Trent Valley in the north
column3: southbound trains operate to Birmingham International and London Euston. The journey time to Birmingham is around 36 minutes. On Sundays
column4: trains operate as far south as Coventry.

column1: == Education ==
Cannock Chase High School is a non-denominational mixed comprehensive with just over 1000 pupils aged 11–18.
Cardinal Griffin Catholic College is a voluntary aided Roman Catholic secondary school with around 950 pupils aged 11–18.

Chase Grammar School (called Lyncroft House School 1980–1996 then Chase Academy until January 2013) is an independent co-educational boarding school with a day nursery and over 200 pupils up to age 19 including many international students.
South Staffordshire College closed its Cannock Campus in July 2017
column2: but reopened it the following summer as the new Cannock Chase Skills and Innovation Hub with courses starting there from September 2018.
